prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruption for the wife who also works from home and handles the kids and chores.

First, I need to understand both sides. The husband chose the bedroom for his office because he prefers the view, even though the basement is available and would offer more privacy and silence. The wife is then responsible for keeping the kids from disturbing him, which restricts her own activities like showering, doing chores, etc. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, so she suggested the basement. But he refuses, and now she's frustrated because he's in her space, and she can't manage her own life.

The key points here are about boundaries and mutual respect. The husband has the option to work from the basement, which would minimize disruption. By choosing the bedroom, he's imposing his work needs on the wife's personal space and responsibilities. The wife is trying to communicate her needs and set boundaries, which is reasonable. If he's unwilling to compromise, he's not respecting her needs. 

The wife isn't being unreasonable by not keeping him undisturbed if he's in a shared space. It's fair for her to expect that if he wants a quiet space, he should use the basement. The husband's choice affects her ability to work and manage the household. So, the author (the wife) isn't in the wrong. The husband should consider her perspective and make the move to the basement. Therefore, the answer should be B (No, she's not in the wrong).
